body: Please read the docs about ignore file and it's effect on ability to remove directories.
The .stignore file isn't used anywhere on the clients. Or am I missing something?

```
/home/dina/Dropbox/ DirNames моё/МедСправки орто [Справка.bmp Выписка1.bmp Thumbs.db Выписка2.bmp Акт.bmp]

remove /home/dina/Dropbox/моё/МедСправки орто: directory not empty
```

There is something in the directory we are not aware off, which means it either hasn't been scanned (for whatever reason, if you delayed the scan, use inotify that's broker or whatever) or it's ignored.

It's _not_ ignored, we need to synchronize absolutely everything. We're using Syncthing-GTK on the client with inotify watcher and just plain syncthing binary on the server with default rescan intervals (60 seconds). I restarted Syncthing on the client but it didn't help. The server rescans often enough to be aware of it and that directory in .stversions has last access time of 13 hours ago (probably when it has been deleted). Even if inotify is the case, if it causes some races inside ST this needs to be fixed.

.stversions has nothing todo with scanning.

If you rescan manually (given inotify was unreliable), I'd expect it to solve itself, unless things are ignored.

I mentioned .stversions because I had no other way to find when the directory was removed (it could be hours or months, I don't check those logs often). I know what that is.

Also, the directory removal originally happened on the other client device (same setup as the described client), it's been synced to the server. Later the client experiencing the issue has connected to the server and could not synchronize that directory (i.e. remove it). The clients almost never connect to each other (work and home devices), they both connect to the server.

Unfortunately, the issue doesn't solve itself, I rescanned manually on both devices to no avail. As in the previous occasions I always have to manually remove the offending directory or it continues to spam the log and pause the puller. Does pausing the puller because of this error affect synchronizing other files?

Actually, this got me thinking. @calmh it seems that given we don't track any metadata about directories, this directory is just out of date, and the fact that there is new files in the directory does not bump it's version, so you end up in a dead end. Do we have any ticket for this, or ideas how to solve it? Bump version of every path component along the path we found?
Puller tries to process as much as it can, so no, this should not affect other items.
@calmh do we have an issue like this open? Even graph puller wouldn't solve this, as we need a graph scanner.

Could you please open this issue until a duplicate is found? It happened to myself recently as well and my connection is much better than that of the other user. Still, this sync lockup happened. The directory has been half-empty, i.e. some of the files were successfully deleted but not all and ST flooded the log with the aforementioned messages about a non-empty directory.

EDIT: the directory is syncing to my tablet and Syncthing for Android definitely uses inotify (in case it causes issues), except on Android 6 (https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing-android/commit/113d712d5f90e3c10c79b44f7deacb20578b5972), so this should be a supported behavior.
I am waiting for @calmh to reply.

body:
This is #114 which I seem to have thought was resolved at some point. Might as well make this the new one instead.

As for solving it, I'm not sure. I guess the bug is that we don't see the dependency between the directory and it's contents. Bumping the version (and making sure things like deleted flags are set/cleared correctly) of parents on change sounds reasonable, although expensive.

A cheaper way would be to check for the reason of a dir deletion failure: If it is due to files existing below it in the database, bump the version of the dir instead of deleting, if it is due to ignored files, give a more descriptive error message (#4476). Does that sound reasonable?

issue.body:
This does not prevent the inconsistent state discussed in #4475, as it would require lots of db lookups for a relatively rare situation. It instead detects this situation when a directory should be deleted due to pulling/remote change, but there exists known valid files inside this directory. In this case the version of the local dir is bumped such that overrides the deletion from the other device.

This change broke one test and I added one more to target this specific scenario. This lead to feature creep in connected code:
 - The broken test `TestIssue3164` does nothing in the model, it operates solely on the sendreceive folder, so I fixed and moved it in rwfolder_test.go.
 - s/f.dbUpdates/dbUpdateChan/ because all other channel involved in pulling are not part of the folder struct and are anyways redefined on every puller iteration.
 - Don't call `ScanFolder` in goroutines on every puller iteration, add paths to `toBeScanned` and "schedule" the scan at the end of pulling (actual scan will anyways only happen after pulling finished). Saves some redundant scans and seems less hackish to me.

Testing: One new test simulating #4475, which in addition also tests the case of an unexpected, unscanned file in a to be deleted folder. No "testing in production" so far, I will do that when I examine the invalid PR situation.
